Rabies cases on the rise in northeastern Thailand

On February 9, Dr. Tawichai from the 9th Disease Prevention and Management Office revealed that in the past few months, the number of rabies infections in northeastern Thailand has increased, with a total of 74 infections.
As of this year (from last October to September), a total of 74 people have been confirmed positive for rabies in Surin Province and Buri Ram Province in the northeastern region.
Everyone has had a rabies vaccination in the past.
The doctor is calling on people to get vaccinated with their pets and to avoid contact with the saliva of animals that may be infected.
Rabies is not only spread by dogs, but also by cats and bats.
If a person gets infected and shows symptoms, almost 100% die, but vaccination before symptoms can prevent death.

FUJI Preventing Accidents by Removing Obstacles  System Development for In-House Vehicles | Mid-Japan Economist  Economic Information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (headquarters in Chiryu), which manufactures and sells robots for installing electronic components and machine tools, has started developing a system to prevent children from being left behind in cars.
A motion sensor in the car detects movement and sends a notification to your phone or chat.
We are currently conducting a trial using our own shuttle buses.
While tragic accidents happen, keep your children safe.

Currently, two vehicles are being used for pick-up and drop-off of children attending the English conversation after-school program "Teracoya THANK (Teracoya Sanku)" which is operated by the company itself within Chiryu City.
Three infrared motion sensors, which detect movement by sensing the temperature difference between a person and their surroundings, were installed in the ceiling of the car.
If the vehicle engine is off and the doors are closed and a certain amount of time has passed, and motion is detected, it will automatically send a notification.
By synchronizing the status and information of the engine and the door, we can prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The notification of the alert is sent through the cloud.
You can call a number you have registered before, and display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses and it will help you avoid mistakes like missing a delivery.
The field test will continue until the end of February.
"While conducting the experiment, we were able to see other peripheral issues besides the system," said Kamiya Toshihiko, chief of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department.
For example, they've been able to address a variety of issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment where drivers can focus on driving.
They are putting their efforts into expanding the solution.
The development of a system to prevent buses from being left behind was triggered by a series of accidents involving buses left behind across the country.
An employee with children proposed an idea to help keep kids safe.

We decided to develop the business by leveraging the know-how we have cultivated through our factory automation (FA) business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, as well as information management.
Fujitsu's anti-displacement system is a big selling point.
The sensor can be mounted on the ceiling with just a pin.
The ease of adding it to existing shuttle vehicles will lower the barrier to entry and aim for widespread adoption.
In the future, we will consider productization while also considering cooperation with childcare centers and kindergartens.

A cat-shaped feeding robot is being introduced at the "Iwa-Shio Aged Jingisukan Bon-Ta Fukui Station" store.
Popular with families because of its cute expressions, etc. = Fukui, Fukui Prefecture, Chuo 2-chome
Fukui Prefecture's food industry, which is suffering from a labor shortage, is introducing robots that deliver food to tables.

The robots' cute expressions and the fact that they can help with cost-cutting measures for store operations and "contactless" customer service to prevent infection of the new coronavirus are popular with families.
"Local restaurants will have a hard time hiring employees or interns, and the spread of feeding robots will increase," said voices from restaurant operators and related parties.
"Jin, Jin, Jin-Gis-Kan♪"
A robot with a light-hearted tune playing in the background displays a cat's face on its screen as it smoothly glides around the restaurant with food.
When they arrive at the table, they talk to the customers like "I've brought your order, nyaa."
In August 2022, the "Iwansen Shokumae Jingisukan Bon Ta Fukui-ekimae Store" in Fukui City's Chuo 2-chome, one of the city's major stores, introduced a cat-shaped feeding robot.
Robots wait near the kitchen and when a customer presses the table number on the screen after loading the ordered food, it autonomously walks to the table to deliver it.
AI (artificial intelligence) voice function and so on are built in, and the cat reacts when the customer touches it, and the cat's facial expressions are also rich.
The "Bonta Group" which manages the store and others has introduced a delivery robot in two stores including the store.

Mr Saito, president of the company, said the reason for the introduction was "labor shortage," and emphasized that it was part of efforts to improve productivity through downsizing and digital transformation (DX).
The labor cost as a percentage of sales is typically 30% but can be reduced to 21-22% with the implementation.

Robots also have a role in collecting used plates after customers have finished eating, which is linked to the efficiency of the clean-up process, and "is fun for families and children, and has promotional value," he added.
The "Rokkan Hoshiyama Fukui Store" in Shinpo-cho, Araki, Fukui, which serves yakitori and hot pot, also introduced a meal delivery robot in August 2020.
SonSan store Hoshiyama Eifuku president, who introduced the system, said, "We couldn't find employees or part-timers. I thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the labor shortage."
At the Fukui store, they have separated the area where employees serve food from the area where robots deliver food.
The cost of renting a robot is the same as the salary of an albino.
In an effort to cut costs, the restaurant is also considering a tablet-based ordering system and self-checkout.
According to the Fukui Prefectural Labor Bureau, the effective recruitment ratio for December 2022 was 6.94 for restaurants and other "customer service" jobs, which are in high demand.

The manager of a net system (Chuo 2-chome, Takami, Fukui) that sells meal delivery robots said, "The shortage of staff in restaurants in Fukui Prefecture has become more serious due to the influence of the coronavirus, and there have been many inquiries about introducing robots."
"I think that local suburban stores will find it even harder to secure staff, and that robots will become more widespread," said Hoshiya.
[Opinion] Echizen Town creates and distributes an ending note to the citizens who hope for it.

Last year, the company published a comprehensive "bereavement handbook" that includes checklists and writing styles for necessary procedures when a family member dies, family trees, and so on, and many people who received it for themselves said it was a trigger.
In each area of the prefecture, there are seminars on how to write an ending note and how to organize one's life, and "end-of-life" has become deeply rooted in the minds of the people.
Echizen Town's ending note is 35 pages long.

The first chapter is a review of your life history, and the following chapters cover your current health and assets, your wishes for future care, end-of-life medical care, funeral arrangements, and burial or cremation.
There is also a section for people to write messages to their loved ones or things they want to do in the rest of their lives.
I say 35 pages but it looks like it could break, you don’t have to fill all the pages.
What do you want to write down for your family and the people around you?
The most important thing is to make your goal clear.
In bookstores and such, there are various types of notes for different purposes, and you can start writing anywhere.
The term "retirement" was coined in 1909, when people were forced to retire.
In 2011, two years later, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
It is said that many people have come to face the reality that "death comes suddenly" and more people are preparing for their own end and final days.
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic, which has spread around the world, is still not under control.
The price of everything has gone up due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and this winter's electricity prices have skyrocketed to unbelievable levels.
On the other hand, wages have not risen enough to keep up with today's high prices, and many people are worried about this.
On the other hand, funeral expenses, nursing care expenses, and grave management fees that used to be shared with children and relatives are now in an era where only children are not uncommon.
Also, while life expectancy has increased significantly in recent years, the risk of dementia and need for care increases as you age.
In the background of the fact that death is not a one-time event and that it is settled, there is also the fact that there is a lot of social anxiety.
Either way, I think everyone would agree that they don’t want to put too much burden on their partner or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular keyword for Ending Note, but it can't be too self-centered.
I don't want to write a wish list, I want to talk to my family and be prepared for that time.

NPO "Kokoro no Hibiku Bunko/Bungakukyoku" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, Your Lifesaver from Tōjinbō"
"Dear Prime Minister, from Tōjinbō, the breakwater of life" I self-published my 10th book with this title.
All the newspapers in the country have taken up the story, and we have received many letters from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the findings of the social and structural environment that causes suicide in Japan, which I have heard directly from those who have planned to commit suicide, and to create a society where people can live with a sense of purpose.

We have been patrolling the cliffs of Tōjinbō, Fukui Prefecture, a notorious suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months, providing support to prevent suicide attempts, including discovering and protecting those who are planning to jump, and helping them to start over.

This book is a summary of the issues raised by the 784 people (2/6 currently) whom I have protected so far, and I am presenting the following seven items to the Prime Minister as necessary measures to prevent suicide in the country.
(1) suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, "human rights violations" are piled up.
( 3 ) The suicidal person is a victim of social and structural organized crime.
(4) Administrative agencies treat citizens who live outside the jurisdiction as "residents" and treat them coldly.
(5) Forcing people with mental illnesses like depression to take medication and committing suicide is treated as an "accident".
(6) The "duty of care" has been forgotten in high-risk suicide areas and is running rampant in commercialism.
(7) The teachings of new religious organizations that cannot be scientifically proven are lies, and the behavior of predicting future disasters and threatening people with gold is intimidation.
The religious organizations that are committing these "fraud and intimidation crimes" should be publicly excluded.

So, from the reviews of this book that I have received, there are many reviews that say, "I was moved by the strong mentalities of those who are involved in this activity," or "The former police officer's appearance is a mirror for police officers," or "He is a bodhisattva who lives by helping others even though he is not one of them," and I would like to introduce one of the reviews here.
I saw a photo in a newspaper and started crying "what was he thinking..."
I've heard that people are committing suicide more often because they're being pushed to the edge by the coronavirus.
it's a very sad thing.
Everyone is like that.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can enjoy our own lives.
I have a lot of respect and gratitude for the staff who have been working so hard, putting in so much effort, for people who are suffering so much, that they would rather die.
I think this activity is very harsh on both the body and mind, so I would like to ask you to continue to speak out from now on, please take care of yourself.
thank you.
kashiko
I hope that all of you, as readers, will become gatekeepers of life in your respective regions.

Pioneers of plant research, including Mount Hayachine collection data, on display at city's cultural property center [Flower scroll] | Iwanichi Online 岩手日日新聞社

An exhibition celebrating the pioneers who built the foundation for research on the flora of Mount Hayachine, known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the Hanamaki City Hasama Integrated Cultural Asset Center until the 12th.
This article collects 124 valuable specimens collected by predecessors and introduces the footprints of predecessors who were involved in the study of plants on Mount Hayachine.

Hayachine's botanical research began with the arrival of Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximovitch (1827-1911) at the end of the Edo period, and continued with the plant collection activities of Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), a native of Shiwa who was guided by Maximovitch.
Maximovitch, who was not allowed to walk freely in the country for foreigners, was asked to collect in Sugawa, and he continued research for three years in Yokohama and Nagasaki as a base.

After Maximovitch returned to Japan, Sugawara continued to support research, and this led to the announcement of the endemic plants of Mount Hayachine, such as "Himekosazura", "Nanboutouuchiso", and "Miyamayamabukisho".

After that, the modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cobanotsumechusa", "Draba japonica", and "Arenaria katoana", which he discovered and named himself on Mount Hayachine in 1903 (Meiji 36) and 1905 (Meiji 38), respectively.
From the exhibition materials, it can be seen that many researchers have revealed important alpine plants.

In addition, the article introduces the work of Shimura Matsuzo (1874-1948), who was the principal of Hachimori Elementary School and conducted plant research while accompanying the survey of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Jiro (1914-1988), who worked at the Ohasama Town Museum of Natural History and was involved in the publication

"There are many studies and connections between people about the background of the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine," says Yoshida Toshihide, a researcher at the center. "We can trace the connections between researchers from local to national levels."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter is about the faith and history of Mount Hayachine, and the second chapter is about the German geologist Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), who built the foundation of Japanese geology, and the features of Mount Hayachine seen from the perspective of geology, with a focus on the surveys conducted by Naumann and others.

Among these, the lighting and air conditioning emissions of seven facilities, including airport terminal buildings, account for about 90% of the total, followed by airport lighting (841 tons) and airport vehicles (710 tons).
